comments.body: We should define source here. Are we only talking about Dockerfiles?
Where should docker images live? My guess is we don't care, but we do assume they will live on a public registry. It might be worth calling that out.

@kelseyhightower also, fyi: Jeff and I have created a 'google-samples' project where we've been putting example images that are 'devrel-managed' (over time there should be an increasing # of these).  I just added the cassandra image there. We have a spreadsheet where we track them that I will send you separately.

We have https://github.com/kubernetes/application-images for "real apps".

We could create another repo in the kubernetes org.
We should also standardize where the images live.
We do care. For one, we'd like to have continuous testing of the examples. We also want to be able to push updated versions.

We should add a point about image versioning:

All images should be tagged with a version number (v1, v2, v3, ...). If the image is rebuilt for any reason, apply a new tag with an incremented version, and update the resource manifests to refer to that version.

comments.body: We do have both individual components, like redis or cassandra, and toy multi-tier applications, like guestbook and k8spetstore. It might be useful to distinguish them.

+1, in openshift we have examples for deploying things like DBs, and then we have examples for deploying a full application framework with a DB.  While you can argue the latter includes all the information of the former, it's much easier for someone looking to just deploy a new DB to start w/ the DB-only example.
I think both are ok here, as long as the example is "educational and informative" I'm not sure how to distinguish the difference, other than a good description in the readme chart.

comments.body:
We need some formatting conventions:
- console vs. shell markdown formatting
- prompts (to distinguish commands from output) vs. copy+paste-friendly commands
- quoted text vs. screenshots vs. ascii animations

Could we require a recording of the whole example, so someone could opt to watch before (or instead of) trying it themselves?

Ascii animations are pretty:
http://blog.jonparrott.com/building-a-paas-on-kubernetes/
https://github.com/redspread/spread

Going to go with:
- Always use shell (Rogue does not support console)
- No prompt
- Output in separate block.

comments.body:
We should have some pedagogical tips, too:
- Progressive disclosure -- introduce conepts at a measured rate, gloss over unnecessary details, and don't overwhelm the user
- https://mkremins.github.io/blog/doors-headaches-intellectual-need/
- reward success / gamification 
  - https://docs.docker.com/mac/step_three/
  - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zRGRJRUWafY&t=25
These seem to fit tutorials rather than examples. That reminds me, I wanted to add that examples are not tutorials.

comments.body:
Thought I commented on this, but can't find it: We're going to have to have some testing conventions, both unit testing and end-to-end testing.

I'd like like to be able to automatically regenerate any command output, since we change that frequently.

We need a convention for parameterization, like `gcr.io/<YOUR-PROJECT-ID>/myapp`. Maybe envsubst and ${PROJECT_ID}? Or sed?

In 1.3, we'll have parameterized templates.
I strongly prefer `<SUB>`. Any time I see `$SUB` or `${SUB}` I think that something else is going to do the substitution for me.
Updated to require angle brackets.

comments.body: I should update that doc before we overhaul examples.

I don't see any mention of namespaces in the current doc.
